channel.title: Mastodon Home Timeline
channel.description: RSS feed for the Mastodon Home timeline

item.title: David Schoppik
item.description: East side shadows, #nyc #photography

item.title: Stefano Maffulli
item.description:
Talking about ill-conceived regulations, today @eff and @pluralistic address another dumpster fire: the “link tax” that France and Australia spearheaded, with the declared intention to limit Google’s power and achieving instead more concentration of power into large corporations.
Recommended read: https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/04/saving-news-big-tech

item.title: Earl K. Miller
item.description:
New paper!
Cytoelectric Coupling: Electric fields sculpt neural activity and “tune” the brain’s infrastructure.Brain waves carry info and alter the brain on the molecular level. This tunes the cytoskeleton, optimizing network function.Work by Dimitris Pinotsis.
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.pneurobio.2023.102465

item.title: David Schoppik
item.description: @ekmiller I got to "Thus, it stands to reason that electric activity and fields could play a direct role by configuring and stabilizing cytoskeleton proteins." but I confess that there was nothing in the preceding paragraphs that let me make that leap with you.Help me out please? What's the experiment that would disprove the the Cytoelectric Coupling Hypothesis? Maybe propose two: one free of all tech considerations, and one that might be achievable now? Thanks!

item.title: David Schoppik
item.description:
TIL that Béla Julesz (of the random dot stimulus, and the "magic eye" autostereogram) so famous in visual psych / neuroscience and Salvador Dali were buddies.
Lots more awesome history of computer-generated art here: https://www.amygoodchild.com/blog/computer-art-50s-and-60s

item.title: Matt Blaze
item.description: Manhattan Bridge, from Manhattan.(Vertically formatted image; you may have to click the preview to see the whole thing.)A dozen times more pixels than there are stories in the naked city at https://www.flickr.com/photos/mattblaze/52841667763(I posted this before but the uploaded image was slightly messed up)#photography

item.title: Jürgen
item.description: “We have unprecedented opportunities here but we are also facing a perfect storm of corporate irresponsibility, widespread deployment, lack of adequate regulation and inherent unreliability.” - Gary Marcus (@garymarcus)#ai #artificialintelligence #llm #llms #chatbot #chatsbots #machinelearning #openai #chatgpt #ethicaltechhttps://www.nytimes.com/2023/05/16/technology/openai-altman-artificial-intelligence-regulation.html

item.title: Lucas C Parra
item.description:
@NicoleCRust @dbarack @ekmiller Here are two more (older) data points on the causal effects of weak electric fields ...on spikes:
https://www.jneurosci.org/content/30/45/15067and network activity:
https://www.jneurosci.org/content/27/11/3030

item.title: Earl K. Miller
item.description: @schoppik Make electric fields oscillate, look at the effects on scaffolding proteins. Bob's your uncle!

item.title: David Schoppik
item.description: @ekmiller how would that disprove the hypothesis? I’m on board with the idea that cytoskeletal proteins carry charge and as such can be influenced by electric fields. It’s everything after that the conceptual advance, right?

item.title: Luiz Pessoa
item.description:
Great talk by @dbarack on neural manifolds, highly recommend it.Around min 30 David states that the manifold idea/findings indicates emergence in the sense of being irreducible to individual neurons. Do others think neural manifolds provide interesting evidence of emergence?If so, along a spectrum of types of emergence, where does it fall?https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zgP8SipIuHA@NicoleCRust @DrYohanJohn
@Gualtiero

item.title: John McCutcheon
item.description: This makes me physically sick. It’s a toxic brew of the artificial scarcity of ‘elite’ institutions, the cheapening of research, and the runaway professionalization of being a kid. https://www.propublica.org/article/college-high-school-research-peer-review-publications

item.title: GeofCox
item.description: So the BLAIR government was warned IN 2002 what would happen to the UK's privatised water systems:“My real concern was about the financial structure of the proposed deal. In my view the transaction created an entity which would prove impossible to regulate.“Large external private equity shareholders would load the company with debt and Ofwat inevitably would lose any regulatory control. For example, it would prove extremely difficult to ensure that water companies invested enough in sewage control."https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/may/20/revealed-warning-to-ministers-over-privatised-water-kept-secret-since-2002

item.title: Nicole Rust
item.description:
This history behind computing and weather control is just so good! Here's a link to a report by von Neumann's colleague, Vladimir K. Zworykin, titled, "Outline of Weather Proposal" (October 1945). It lays out the plan for weather prediction and then control with an endorsement at the end (p 17) from von Neumann himself:
I agree with you completely that once the methods of prediction are sufficiently advanced the immediate following step should be prediction from hypothetical situations. In other words: exploring the consequences of various controllable changes in the absorption and reflection properties of the ground and of a number of suitable atmospheric phenomena which can be brought on artificially. This would provide a basis for scientific approach to influencing the weather. I agree with you that our present inability to influence the weather is not due to the fact that the energies involved in weather are too great, since the most conspicuous meteorological phenomena originate in unstable or metastable situations which could be controlled, or at least directed, by the release of perfectly practical amounts of energy.
Hmmm. You might note that this has not happened. Well ... at least we got computers (and weather forecasting) out of the effort.https://journal.meteohistory.org/index.php/hom/article/view/65

item.title: Earl K. Miller
item.description: @schoppik There's always the null hypothesis. No effect on proteins. If there are effects, are they good or bad?I am not a molecular biologist. I can't tell you the deets. But others can and hopefully will.

item.description: Freely available textbooks online. http://labrigger.com/blog/2023/05/20/free-textbooks-online-with-internet-archive/

item.title: David Schoppik
item.description: @ekmiller how do you envision that the electrical fields confine their effects to neurons? Wouldn’t they also affect the cytoskeleton in nearby vasculature? Or glia? Asking bc it’s hard to apply “good” or “bad” to trophic/metabolic players.

item.title: Nicole Rust
item.description: Wait - what? Kurt Vonnegut too! I promise that I'll stop talking about the history of weather control research as soon as it gets boring. But that moment isn't here yet.Anyone who has read Kurt Vonnegut's Cat's Cradle will remember ice-nine (which turns water solid). So K. Vonnegut got that idea from his brother, Bernard Vonnegut who worked for GE and was one of the first to control weather (circa 1946) by throwing some dry ice out of a plane into the clouds to make it snow.https://www.ge.com/news/reports/cool-science-vonnegut-ge-research

item.title: Carl Zimmer
item.description: Why squirrels get dark in the city https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2023.02.02.526896v2
